newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Cyprus plays down Turkish missile warning.
newsitem.headline: Cyprus plays down Turkish missile warning.

text.p: Cyprus on Thursday dismissed a warning by Turkey that it would attack the island if it needed to protect the Turkish Cypriot community in the north.
"These threats from Turkey are nothing new," said Cypriot government spokesman Yiannakis Cassoulides. "We have heard such threats before."

Turkey has accused the Cypriot government of trying to change the balance of forces on the divided island with a deal announced last weekend to buy Russian anti-aircraft missiles that could neutralise Turkish air superiority.
The Cypriot government says the S-300 missile system is purely defensive.

Turkey invaded Cyprus in 1974 in response to a Greek Cypriot coup inspired by the military then ruling Athens. Around 30,000 troops are based in north Cyprus, declared a breakaway Turkish Cypriot state in 1983 recognised only by Ankara.

"What was needed in 1974 and what did we do? We will do the same again. If needed, we will strike," Turkey's Defence Minister Turhan Tayan told the state-run TRT television channel in an interview on Wednesday.
Cassoulides said there was no justification for a Turkish attack. "If there is any danger of war right now it is a danger of a war of nerves," he said.
The United States is to send an envoy to the island at the weekend to try to reduce tensions between Greeks and Turks.

Washington has criticised Cyprus, saying the missile purchase would introduce a destabilising new military element and complicate peace moves. Britain's deputy high commissioner to Cyprus expressed his concern at a meeting with the foreign minister on Thursday, a British spokesman said.
